pros: Great environment and a great community

job_title: Assistant Professor (Non-tenure Track) in Monmouth, OR
pros: Overall a good work environment, my colleagues are kind and knowledgeable, enjoy getting to know folks on the smaller campus (compared to a bigger school)
cons: Main issue is the pay, faculty here are paid quite a bit less than most state schools in Oregon

review_title: Good colleagues, good benefits, low pay.
pros: Great colleagues with a focus on intellectual pursuits and dedication to community work.
cons: Low pay compared to similar teaching and learning institutions.

pros: Nice place to work. People help each other.
cons: There is no cons that I can think of.

review_title: Great coworkers and environment, with room for structural improvements
job_title: Director of Academic Services in Monmouth, OR
pros: I really enjoy working with the staff, faculty, and students at WOU. Like any workplace, there are exceptions, but fewer than I've encountered in other jobs. There are a few loud voices with complaints about working here, and they seem to get most of the press attention, but most people agree that it is a good place to work. Not perfect, but definitely better than any other place I've worked! The benefits are also really good.
cons: WOU is a small university, especially compared to its sibling that is half an hour south. This has both pros and cons: employees and students don't feel lost in the crowd, and can really get involved and make an impact. But the flipside is that we have fewer resources, our tech isn't as snazzy, etc. Staff often have more responsibility.

pros: The students are nit entitled and are there to learn
cons: The salary should be higher

pros: Very friendly and student focused
cons: Pay below other local universities, not very innovative

review_title: Great place to work if you're tired of saving the world every week
pros: Nobody's betting the business on some obscure technology that you're supposed to invent. There's room to grow without insane deadlines and pressure.
cons: Occasional political drama that affects and/or restricts your decision making ability.

pros: Flexible schedule, really attentive and compassionate scheduling people
cons: The HR and payroll side is really slow. Really inattentive and you’re able fall through the cracks easily.

pros: Nice coworkers and lovely campus for walking

pros: The benefits are good and it's a smaller University.
cons: Faculty definitely thinks very highly of themselves and themselves only. Because of that, the staff seems to try to exercise the small bits of personal power that they have and make things difficult for other staff members, when there should be the common goal of helping students with their education. Poor communication everywhere. Administration has degraded under the current President causing chaos in leadership. It's been very sad to see this decline.

review_title: Amazing Work Experience, a few drawbacks.
job_title: Office Specialist II in Monmouth, OR
pros: Dedicated and Team-Oriented Colleagues; Beautiful Campus; Positive Work-Life Balance.
cons: Recent Financial Downturn (Sept. 2019 & beyond); Administration Issues; Lack of Compassion for employees laid-off; Lack of transparency from upper-management.

review_title: Too many high paid VPs, disgruntled staff
pros: Great benefits as a state institution.
cons: Unclassified staff have no representation. University doesn't walk the walk when it comes to diversity and representation among staff and faculty.

pros: Kind coworkers, engagement with student populace.
cons: Strict work culture, little room for disagreement.

review_title: A quaint campus with engaged students . . . but there are very few resources to go around.
pros:
The tenure requirements are heavily weighted toward teaching.  
Some departments allow for a high degree of autonomy re: teaching. 
A concerted effort to publish is likely rewarded with less expectations for institutional service. 
Low research requirements (if you're into that).
cons:
The salary here for an Assistant Professor is perhaps the lowest in the country - it is obscene, really.  New Assistant Professor salary at WOU: $42,000. 
Sharing of resources equally is often the go-to rather than merit based pay. 
Low enrollment in many programs in summer mean no guaranteed summer teaching opportunities.  
If you're into publication and research you'll be recognized and quickly tenured in many departments; however, you'll likely be doing it largely alone as many other faculty don't pursue research as a way to advance their careers.  
Relatively few opportunities in many departments for socializing and community building . . . Monmouth is not Portland. 
With the breakup of the OUS system (2014), financial future is in question.

pros: Multiple experience in differing duties.
cons: Sometimes offices are siloed within the university.

job_title: Lead Web Developer in Monmouth, OR
pros: I am the lead web developer for The Research Institute at Western Oregon University.  The people are top notch, intelligent, collaborative.  Working atmosphere is congenial and fairly laid back most of the time.  I can pretty much work with whatever technology I feel is best suited for the job at hand.  A lot of freedom.  The benefit package is outstanding.
cons: Low pay, some bureaucracy, lack of funding for career development opportunities.   Being the only developer on staff is tough sometimes because you really need to push yourself forward - nobody is going to help you with that.

review_title: A Decent Place to be a Student Worker
job_title: GIS Research Specialist in Monmouth, OR
pros: I enjoyed the staff and one professor who I worked with during my time here. It seemed most of the people were interested in me making a difference in my future.
cons: On the other hand, I there were several professors who did quite the opposite and did not care. There was one particular who originally hired me and disappeared. Someone else much better took me into their hands. Also, there is no guarantee you will always get the hours you need.

review_title: Love the people I work with
job_title: Administrative Program Assistant in Monmouth, OR
pros:
Small university and faculty that focus on the students.  The salary is fair and the benefits are great.  

In the division I work in, I truly love working with the faculty.
cons: We are union represented and I am not a big fan of unions.  I do see that there are benefits, but when it comes to salary, I would prefer to be paid based on my own merit.

review_title: Convenient work for students, not always a walk in the park
job_title: Parking Enforcement Officer in Monmouth, OR
pros: Right next to the university housing, helps you get to know the campus better, good experience for law enforcement students, and one can often do homework while working during down time.
cons: Shifts are not regular (schedule-wise), and training is not adequate for a student worker to be able to handle the everyday emergencies and possible situations of a university campus. For example, as the front desk representative of public safety during an emergency bomb or shooting incident, the first call comes to me. Due to improper training or lack thereof, I may not know how to properly handle such a dire situation.

pros: Many faculty and staff have integrity and are committed to helping students who show initiative to succeed.
cons:
Burnout among faculty and staff is common due to working environment in which the reward for good work is to have more work assigned.
Upper administration unwilling or unable to engage in effective strategic planning. 
Upper administration focused on reducing costs and maintaining the status quo, rather than stimulating and rewarding innovation and making strategic investments for the future.

pros: Better than minimum wage, relatively easy since I had already taken the courses I tutored for. Friendly and helpful coworkers.
cons: Schedule is determined by the students and they can back out of meetings with little or no notice. Tutoring had to be done on campus in a specific location.

pros: People are nice. And Office culture is nice. But I don't think will be personal growth.
cons: No. There is no training, but I think the job is not too hard, just communicate with student and professors. The leadership need to improve.

pros: Relaxed scheduling made it easy to work around classes. Most teachers provided adequate supplementary materials to aid in assisting students.
cons: Communication between faculty and tutor schedulers was poor; on days prior to exams the number of students coming in would easily triple while the number of tutors stayed the same.

review_title: A good place to work, though maybe not the highest pay
pros: Great campus, nice staff, good benefits, mostly relaxed (yet professional) atmosphere.
cons: On the low side for pay, not many training opportunities, zero opportunity for advancement.
